content: Perhaps this was the less-than-suttle-way for a "loan shark" to remind someone in the newspaper that he wanted his money back. ++http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/090423/oddities/australia_animal_shark_media_offbeat quote: Shark dumped on Australian paper's doorstep Thu Apr 23, 12:13 PM SYDNEY (AFP) - A live shark was found dumped on the doorstep of a newspaper's office in a coastal town in southeast Australia, police said Thursday. A passer-by alerted police in Warrnambool, Victoria, shortly after midnight that a shark was lying at the front door of the town's Standard newspaper. "We arrived and poured some water on it just to see if it was still breathing and it kicked around for a little while," said Constable Jarrod Dwyer, who said the shark was about 70 centimetres (two feet four inches) long. Dwyer said they took the shark to the town's breakwater in a borrowed bucket of water, and released it into the sea. The fish, identified as a Port Jackson shark, which is regarded as harmless to humans except for two dorsal spines reputed to be venomous, swam off. The newspaper "had no ideas of any person that wished them any harm or wished to send them any type of message, so we're a little dumbfounded at this stage," Dwyer said. (...) If caught, the person responsible for dumping the shark would be charged with cruelty to animals, police said.

A passer-by alerted police in Warrnambool, Victoria, shortly after midnight that a shark was lying at the front door of the town's Standard newspaper. "We arrived and poured some water on it just to see if it was still breathing and it kicked around for a little while," said Constable Jarrod Dwyer, who said the shark was about 70 centimetres (two feet four inches) long. Dwyer said they took the shark to the town's breakwater in a borrowed bucket of water, and released it into the sea. The fish, identified as a Port Jackson shark, which is regarded as harmless to humans except for two dorsal spines reputed to be venomous, swam off. The newspaper "had no ideas of any person that wished them any harm or wished to send them any type of message, so we're a little dumbfounded at this stage," Dwyer said. (...) If caught, the person responsible for dumping the shark would be charged with cruelty to animals, police said.
reply: Perhaps this was the less-than-suttle-way for a "loan shark" to remind someone in the newspaper that he wanted his money back. ++http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/090423/oddities/australia_animal_shark_media_offbeat
title: live shark found dumped at Aussie newspaper's doorstep
